author: By Emma Bubola
title: Italian Justice Ministry Moves to Release Iranian Man Sought by the U.S.
description: The request to revoke the man’s arrest came only days after Iran released an Italian journalist. Iranian state news said the man was now in Tehran, but Italy has not confirmed that.
content: Italy’s justice minister has requested the revocation of the arrest of an Iranian man sought by the United States for allegedly providing material used in an attack that killed three American soldiers, the Italian government announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Palisades Lost
description: Days after a devastating wildfire, residents of Pacific Palisades have started sifting through the ruins, and their memories.
content: This weekend was supposed to be an ordinary one in Pacific Palisades. Boy Scout Troop 223 was planning a weekend camp-out at Malibu Creek. The local youth baseball tryouts were scheduled at Palisades Recreation Center’s Field of Dreams. Sunday morning was a time for the farmer’s market just off Sunset Boulevard, for picking over produce and grass-fed meat while kibitzing with neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jody Becker
title: Synagogue Congregation Grieves in Borrowed Home After L.A. Fires
description: Across Los Angeles, congregants displaced by the blazes met for their first services in borrowed churches, synagogues and other temples.
content: Rabbi Jill Gold Wright looked out at her congregation Friday night and uttered a simple statement, with a significant pause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Middle-Class Dreams Lie in Ruins in Palisades Mobile Home Park
description: The Los Angeles wildfires destroyed mobile homes, leaving people who saved to build a middle-class life digging through rubble for anything that remained.
content: Up on Amalfi Drive in the Pacific Palisades neighborhood of Los Angeles, luxury homes owned by celebrities are still standing. But down at the Pacific Palisades Bowl Mobile Estates, a mobile home community on Pacific Coast Highway just across from the beach, all of the nearly 200 homes are destroyed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova and Dado Galdieri
title: The Mafia’s Grip on a Brazilian Lottery Seemed Invincible. Until the Apps Came.
description: Digital gambling could spell the end for a lottery run by criminal gangs that has been a fixture of Brazilian life for decades.
content: Taiza Carine da Costa got her first taste of gambling when she was just 9.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zakiya Dalila Harris
title: She Published a Blockbuster Book. Was It a Blessing or a Curse?
description: In Nnedi Okorafor’s new novel, “Death of the Author,” a once-struggling writer grapples with power, privilege, agency and art after her book becomes a life-changing hit.
content: In 2019, after Nnedi Okorafor had grown tired of being called an “afrofuturist,” she coined a new descriptor for herself on her blog: “africanfuturist.” Both terms concern the Black diaspora, Okorafor wrote, but africanfuturism is specifically rooted in Africa. “I needed to regain control of how I was being defined,” she asserted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon and Wesley Parnell
title: At Home, Her Life Was Modest. As ‘Killadamente,’ She Inspired Millions.
description: Carol Acosta transformed herself into a social media influencer with a message of self-love. The Dominican American star died last week at the age of 27.
content: As a Dominican American girl growing up in a small, immigrant neighborhood in Newark, Carol Acosta was relentlessly taunted about her weight. Her home life was chaotic, too: Neighbors said they heard shouting matches from inside her family’s small apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Celebrity Moguls
description: We cover the rise of entrepreneurship in Hollywood.
content: “Please just keep in mind,” Nikki Glaser exhorted Hollywood’s A-list while hosting the Golden Globes last week: “The point of making art is not to win an award. The point of making art is to start a tequila brand so popular that you never have to make art again.” The stars arrayed before her chuckled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi and Mimi Dwyer
title: On a Screen, Devastation
description: As catastrophic fires consume homes in California, the owners can watch the unfolding tragedy through Ring and Nest cameras.
content: The lens of the Nest Cam faced the yard, pointing toward the infinity pool of the home cut into the rugged hillside of Pacific Palisades. Across the country, the couple who own the home watched in horror as the orange fireball grew, until the flames began licking the side of the pool, then jumped to the roofline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff
title: An Expert Explains the Palisades Fire’s Behavior
description: The blaze, which has burned 23,700 acres in western Los Angeles since starting on Jan. 7, has been tricky to wrangle. Its northern edge, including Mandeville Canyon, is the area of biggest concern, said Robert Clark of Cal Fire.
content: The Palisades fire continues to challenge firefighters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Kamala Harris Shares a Trump-less Photo of Presidents at Jimmy Carter’s Funeral
description: Pictures shared on social media by the vice president and by the Carter Center prominently showed other past presidents in attendance.
content: Former President Jimmy Carter’s funeral on Thursday brought together five current and former presidents. But photos of the group later shared to social media by Vice President Kamala Harris and the Carter Center left one of them out of frame: President-elect Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Writing Fantasy Came Naturally. Reality Was Far More Daunting.
description: After winning just about every major science fiction and fantasy award, Nnedi Okorafor explores a traumatic event in her own history in her most autobiographical novel yet.
content: When Nnedi Okorafor was 19, she woke up disoriented in a hospital room. Fluorescent pink and green grasshoppers and praying mantises bounced around her hospital bed, making strange clicks. An enormous crow threw itself against the window, trying to break in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Kahn
title: Chronic Pain Is a Hidden Epidemic. It’s Time for a Revolution.
description: As many as two billion people suffer from it — including me. Can science finally bring us relief?
content: Here’s a strange story: One day two summers ago, I woke up because my arms — both of them — hurt. Not the way they do when you’ve slept in a funny position, but as if the tendons in my forearms and hands were moving through mud. What felt like sharp electric shocks kept sparking in my fingers and sometimes up the inside of my biceps and across my chest. Holding anything was excruciating: a cup, a toothbrush, my phone. Even doing nothing was miserable. It hurt when I sat with my hands in my lap, when I stood, when I lay flat on the bed or on my side. The slightest pressure — a bedsheet, a watch band, a bra strap — was intolerable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Texas Has a Point About Online Pornography
description: All 50 states ban minors from purchasing adult material offline.
content: When does freedom for adults become cruelty to children?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: Newsom Suspends State Environmental Rules for Rebuilding After Fires
description: California is one of America’s most difficult and costly places to build — a driving factor behind the state’s longstanding affordable housing shortage.
content: Governor Gavin Newsom has signed a broad executive order that aims to make it easier to rebuild after the fires by suspending California’s costly and time-consuming environmental review process for homeowners and businesses whose property was damaged or destroyed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Even Without Its Most Famous Son, Carter’s Hometown Remains a Destination
description: Plains, Ga., joins a collection of other small towns known for their part in presidential history. That can provide a steady source of tourism.
content: Plains has no major hotel, a single small gas station and only a couple of restaurants, neither of which is usually open for dinner. Still, for the longest time, the tiny town had something that no other place in Georgia did: Jimmy Carter making it his home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Canada and Mexico Are Sending Teams to Help California Fight the Fires
description: Air tankers, firefighters and technicians from the neighboring countries are on their way to Los Angeles in a show of solidarity.
content: When Canada was fighting wildfires in Alberta, Quebec and British Columbia in 2023, blazes that would go on to eventually burn more than 45 million acres, more than 2,000 American firefighters helped extinguish the flames.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins and Yan Zhuang
title: Part of Eastern Malibu Is ‘Gone,’ Mayor Says, as Palisades Fire Rages
description: A third of eastern Malibu has been destroyed by the blaze, including the communities of Big Rock and Carbon Mesa and a famed stretch of Pacific Coast Highway, officials said.
content: The Palisades fire has decimated Malibu, destroying around a third of the coastal city’s eastern flank and much of a picturesque stretch of Pacific Coast Highway, officials said late Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louis Staples
title: Martha, Nigella, Meghan Markle?
description: Her every move seems to spark a backlash. But by launching a lifestyle show on Netflix, Meghan may yet find her fairy-tale ending.
content: “This is about connecting with friends … making new friends … and just learning,” says Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, in the trailer for her forthcoming Netflix series, “With Love, Meghan.” The nearly two-minute ad, set to the hopeful tones of “Do You Believe in Magic” by the Lovin’ Spoonful, which rolled out to much fanfare this month, casts Meghan as something of a domestic goddess. We see her wearing an apron and carrying artfully presented baskets of intimidatingly fresh-looking vegetables, creating colorful floral arrangements and even harvesting her own honey. As she decorates freshly baked treats, we hear one of her many hashtaggable phrases: “Love is in the details.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giles Harvey, Simon Vance, Adrienne Hurst, Tanya Pérez, Krish Seenivasan, John Woo, Aaron Esposito, Catherine Anderson and Joel Thibodeau
title: The Sunday Read: ‘What Alice Munro Knew’
description: The Nobel-winning author’s husband was a pedophile who targeted her daughter and other children. Why did she stay silent?
content: “My life has gone rosy, again,” Alice Munro told a friend in a buoyant letter of March 1975. For Munro, who was then emerging as one of her generation’s leading writers, the previous few years had been blighted by heartbreak and upheaval: a painful separation from her husband of two decades; a retreat from British Columbia back to her native Ontario; a series of brief but bruising love affairs, in which, it seems, Munro could never quite make out the writing on the wall. “This time it’s real,” she wrote, speaking of a new romantic partner, Gerald Fremlin, the emphasis acknowledging that her friend had heard these words before. “He’s 50, free, a good man if I ever saw one, tough and gentle like in the old tire ads, and this is the big thing — grown-up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Abigail McGrath, Founder of an Experimental Theater, Dies at 84
description: She was an aspiring actor when she was cast in an Andy Warhol film called “Tub Girls.” But she was best known for the beloved Off Center Theater.
content: Abigail McGrath was an aspiring actor with a day job as a copywriter at an ad agency — and working weekend nights manning the door at Max’s Kansas City, among other side hustles — when her friend Susan Hoffman, otherwise known as Viva, a member of Andy Warhol’s entourage, asked her to find a tub for a film Warhol had cast her in. An unusual tub, she stressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Tan and Ryan Mac
title: Watch Duty, a Wildfire-Tracking App, Provides a Lifeline in Los Angeles
description: A nonprofit runs the app with volunteers and full-time employees, including retired firefighters and dispatchers, to provide live updates on fire conditions.
content: Paulette Lifton woke up on her 67th birthday on Tuesday morning in a panic to smoke pluming in the distance of her home in the Granada Hills neighborhood of Los Angeles. The first person she called was her sister Annette.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer and Madeleine Ngo
title: Inside Elon Musk’s Plan for DOGE to Slash Government Costs
description: Mr. Musk has turned to Silicon Valley to help recruit executives who will take up unofficial positions across the federal government.
content: An unpaid group of billionaires, tech executives and some disciples of Peter Thiel, a powerful Republican donor, are preparing to take up unofficial positions in the U.S. government in the name of cost-cutting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: How to Protect Your Home From Wildfires
description: Thousands of wildfires rage across California every year. No matter where you are, it’s important to learn how to minimize their threat.
content: The wildfires that began in and around Los Angeles last week spread with terrifying speed, forcing many people to flee the flames with little warning. As firefighters work to contain the blazes, the disaster serves as a reminder of the dangers of climate change, which has been found to increase both the severity and frequency of wildfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Richard Hays, 76, Dies; Theologian Who Had Stunning Change of Heart
description: He released a thunderclap into the evangelical world by asserting that a deeper reading of the Bible revealed that same-sex relationships are not sinful.
content: For decades, conservative Christians opposed to homosexuality cited the Bible scholarship of Richard B. Hays, the dean of Duke Divinity School, who provided a full-on argument from Scripture against gay relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: She Threw a Great Party. And No Matter Your Party, You Were Invited.
description: In “The Woman Who Knew Everyone,” Meryl Gordon offers a thorough biography of Perle Mesta, Washington’s colorful, and oft-mocked, “hostess with the mostes’.”
content: The iPhone can feel like a Oujia board. I typed “Perle Mesta” into a text message and the words were immediately rendered in ALL CAPS. Spooked, I tried again with a few other weirdly spelled proper names, but only hers produced this assertive autocorrect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Federal Court Blocks Transfer of Guantánamo Convict to Prison in Iraq
description: The Iraqi prisoner had sued the Biden administration, saying he would be at risk for abuse at a prison in his homeland.
content: A federal judge on Saturday temporarily prevented the U.S. government from transferring a disabled prisoner to Iraq from the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, while the judge considered the prisoner’s claim that he would be at risk for abuse and inadequate health care there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon, Tavares Cebola and Joao Silva
title: This Part of Mozambique Was Like Paradise. Now It’s a Terrorist Hotbed.
description: Islamic State militants have rampaged across the northern Cabo Delgado Province for more than seven years. The government says the situation has stabilized. Residents tell a different story.
content: In October, we traveled to the Cabo Delgado Province in northern Mozambique to understand how terrorists who claim an affiliation with the Islamic State have gained a foothold and wreaked havoc on Muslims and Christians alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: How Poshmark Is Trying to Make Resale Work Again
description: The once high-flying platform for secondhand clothes was bought by a huge South Korean tech company. Can tech fixes make peer-to-peer selling seamless?
content: Lauren Eager got into thrifting in high school. It was a way to find cheap, interesting clothes while not contributing to the wastefulness of fast fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Fed-Up Voters in Louisiana Wanted a Change. They Drafted an ‘Old Ball Coach.’
description: Sid Edwards was a high school football coach who had never run for office. Now, he’s the mayor of Baton Rouge, Louisiana’s second-largest city.
content: As Sid Edwards tells it, he was driving through a gusty storm, with lightning streaking the sky, when he reached a fateful crossroads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacey Young
title: I’m a Federal Employee. This Is What We Need Most in the Trump Era.
description: Practical support matters more than encouragement.
content: Federal employees like me have been hearing a lot in recent weeks about how important it is for us to stay in our jobs, despite President-elect Donald Trump’s open animosity toward much of the federal work force. We’ve been told by friends, relatives and good-government advocates that a well-functioning government — and the survival of our democracy — depends on it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: It’s Time for a Fashion Revolution
description: An unprecedented number of new designers have an opportunity to once again change how we dress. They should dare to seize it.
content: This year will be a year of seismic change in fashion. That much is a given.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Trump Calls Officials Handling Los Angeles Wildfires ‘Incompetent’
description: Governor Gavin Newsom and Los Angeles County authorities have invited President-elect Donald J. Trump to tour the devastation, but he has not publicly responded.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump offered fresh criticism early Sunday of the officials in charge of fighting the Los Angeles wildfires, calling them “incompetent” and asking why the blazes were not yet extinguished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Monday Briefing: Number of Missing Rises in L.A.
description: Plus, how cured ham fixed an antique organ in France.
content: Firefighters made some progress to contain the multiple wildfires across the city on Sunday as more desert winds arrived. The blazes have killed at least 16 people, and Sheriff Robert Luna of Los Angeles County said that the number of missing increased by the hour. Follow our live coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 582
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Jan. 13, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Give In to Gravity
description: Adam Levav makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: What Happens When There Are Fewer Spaces to Park?
description: Hundreds of cities have cut back parking requirements for real estate projects. That’s led to more housing development, but it has also resulted in backlash from residents.
content: Two billion parking spots dot the country, by some estimates. That’s roughly seven spaces for every car, adding up to an area about the size of West Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: More Public Restrooms Are Sorely Needed
description: Readers offer solutions in New York and elsewhere. Also: A soldier’s moral trauma; doctors weighing patients; access to environmental data.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patti Davis
title: The Dream of California Is Up in Smoke
description: Los Angeles seemed like paradise. Who could have imagined where it would lead?
content: I’ve heard people say they couldn’t live in Los Angeles because they’d miss the changing of the seasons, but spending much of my childhood on a ranch in Malibu, I watched as the storms rolled in during the winter months, the land turning green and lush, then blossoming in wild colors and sweet scents in spring, browning and drying out in summer before the air turned crisp in autumn and orange leaves fell from trees to blanket the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘She Was Often the Only Bright Spot in My Otherwise Grim Days’
description: A vendor with a sharp memory, puzzling behavior on the A train and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Resisting Oppression With Creativity, Two Ways
description: The Out-Front! Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday featured thrilling works by Angie Pittman (“Black Life Chord Changes”) and Kyle Marshall (“Joan”).
content: “It’s after the end of the world. Don’t we know that yet?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Debra Kamin
title: ‘Will Pay Any Amount’: Private Firefighters Are in Demand in L.A.
description: Hiring a private fire crew costs thousands of dollars a day, and most work through government contracts or with insurance companies. Some wealthy property owners are calling them in directly.
content: Monument Street, which cuts through the center of Pacific Palisades, tells two starkly different stories of the fire that has engulfed the community. On one side, lots where multimillion-dollar houses once stood are now ash and rubble. On the other, an outdoor shopping mall whose tenants include Chanel, the men’s clothier Buck Mason and an upscale sushi restaurant, is largely intact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Feintzeig
title: How to Make It to Jan. 31 Without Losing Your Mind
description: Lotion! Heating pads! Sketchy space heaters!
content: I’d like to put forth January for worst month of the year. February requires you to trudge through only 28 or so frigid days, with the promise of spring on the other side. December had parties and procrastination and excuses to suspend conventions like meals per day (third dinner) and portion size (a cocktail fit for Ina Garten). In January, you’re staring down 31 bleak days, the legal limit, with no hope of things turning around any time soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ségolène Le Stradic
title: Hams in the Belfry: How a Cash-Poor French Cathedral Fixed Its Organ
description: A dispute over a project to cure hams in a bell tower underscored the difficulties that churches in France face trying to pay for restorations.
content: Struggling to raise funds for the restoration of his cathedral’s antique organ, a priest from St.-Flour, a small town in France’s heartland, came up with a creative solution. He turned one of the bell towers into a curing workshop where farmers could hang their hams to dry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: ‘Now Is the Time of Monsters’
description: Four trends are converging to make life much scarier.
content: Donald Trump is returning, artificial intelligence is maturing, the planet is warming, and the global fertility rate is collapsing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: The Secret of Life Is Not to Be Frightened
description: The writer and painter Frederic Tuten, 88, insists, “I’m beginning again.”
content: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, Frederic Tuten explains, in his own words, what continues to motivate him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Syria Confronts an Immense Challenge: Justice for Assad Regime Crimes
description: The rebel alliance that took power has vowed to prosecute senior figures from the ousted government, but accountability will be hard to achieve in a vulnerable, divided and battered country.
content: There seem to be no limits to the dark revelations laid bare by the downfall of Syria’s 54-year Assad regime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Druse Leader Aims to Secure Place for Syrian Minorities
description: Despite assurances from the rebels-turned-leaders, members of some religious groups worry what life will be like for them in a post-Assad Syria.
content: As Western diplomats explore establishing ties with the rebels who took power in Syria, a religious minority has been conducting its own diplomatic push to ensure protections for its members as the country rebuilds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Restart Your Sourdough Starter
description: Feed it some flour and water, and watch as it blooms back into funky, bubbly excellence, ready for pancakes or waffles.
content: Good morning. How’s your sourdough starter? Maybe you spun one up during the pandemic, used it obsessively for a while and then sporadically and then not at all. It sits forlorn and slightly scary in a tub in the back of the fridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Kim Barker, Constant Méheut and Michael Schwirtz
title: Pardoned by Trump, Manafort Is Back and Looking for Foreign Work
description: The president-elect’s 2016 campaign chairman, four years after receiving clemency, is testing the international market with a team of Trump-linked consultants.
content: Four years after receiving a pardon from President Donald J. Trump for crimes related to foreign lobbying, Paul Manafort is again seeking business from political interests abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Tan, Yan Zhuang and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Firefighters Battle to Keep Palisades Blaze From Pushing Into Mandeville Canyon
description: Mandeville Canyon Road, including multimillion-dollar homes with panoramic city views, was out of immediate danger for now, fire officials said.
content: Fire officials battling the Palisades blaze, the largest in the Los Angeles area, said late Saturday that they had made progress, managing to stop the fire from pushing downhill into a residential area of Mandeville Canyon by removing dry vegetation that could help it spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren
title: Trump Discusses Tax Cuts for New Yorkers With G.O.P. Lawmakers
description: The president-elect told Republicans from New York, New Jersey and California to come up with a plan for increasing the state and local tax deduction — a move that would benefit their constituents.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump reiterated his support for undoing a major provision of his 2017 tax law on Saturday when he told more than a dozen House Republicans at his Florida estate to come up with a plan for increasing the state and local tax deduction, according to four lawmakers who attended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Soumya Karlamangla
title: Before Taking Office, L.A.’s Mayor Said She Would Not Go Abroad
description: Mayor Karen Bass of Los Angeles has been criticized for being out of the country when the wildfires broke out. Three years ago, she promised in an interview to cut back on her world travel and focus on the city.
content: After the first rally in her campaign for mayor of Los Angeles in 2021, Karen Bass spoke candidly about what she saw as a potential drawback to the job — a lack of world travel and involvement in global affairs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: In Congress, Push for Proxy Voting for New Parents Draws Bipartisan Support
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 12, 2025.
content: “This job is not made for young women, for working families, and it’s definitely not made for regular people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazaneen Ghaffar
title: Stronger Santa Ana Winds to Return, and Risk May Rise to ‘Extreme’
description: After a brief break on Sunday afternoon, another prolonged round of gusty Santa Ana winds is expected to develop, forecasters say.
content: Winds picked up again early on Sunday across Southern California, reaching close to 70 miles an hour near the western and eastern San Gabriel Mountains and the Highway 14 corridor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Kristi Noem Used Troops for Border Protection, but Not for Flood Aid at Home
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump picked the South Dakota governor to head the Homeland Security Department, which includes the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
content: When historic flooding ravaged southeastern South Dakota last summer, leaving homes and businesses in ruins, Gov. Kristi Noem made a controversial decision: She chose not to deploy the state’s National Guard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Awards Medal of Freedom to Pope Francis
description: President Biden, a Catholic, awarded the medal with distinction to the pontiff, to whom he has turned for personal guidance.
content: President Biden awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom with Distinction to Pope Francis on Saturday, granting one of the nation’s highest honors to a figure he called “the People’s Pope.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,304
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Jan. 13, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: The Eaton Fire Is Now One of California’s Deadliest
description: At least 16 people have died in the blaze, east of downtown Los Angeles. Officials expect the number to rise as the police make their way through devastated neighborhoods.
content: At least 16 people have been killed in the Eaton fire, making the blaze, near Pasadena, among the deadliest in California history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Kahn
title: 5 Things We Know About Chronic Pain
description: After developing chronic pain, I started looking into what scientists do — and still don’t — understand about the disease. Here is what I learned.
content: Most of us don’t think about pain until we have it. And when we do, it’s typically something we get over after a few days or weeks. That was my own experience, until the summer of 2023. One day I woke to find that my arms hurt. There was no obvious explanation, nothing I’d done. The pain was intense. I couldn’t do much of anything: drive, cook, type, even sleep. I’d always been a healthy person who did a lot of sports, and I figured this strange pain was just bad luck. But as weeks turned into months, and no cause or treatment could be found, I began to realize that I wasn’t alone: that all around me was an ongoing epidemic of chronic pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: 3 Humvees and Military Supplies Stolen From Army Reserve Warehouse
description: The police in Tustin, Calif., said the Humvees, as well as binoculars, bayonets and machine gun vehicle mounts, had been stolen from an Army Reserve Center.
content: Investigators on Sunday were seeking more information about the theft of three Humvees, more than a dozen bayonets, seven free-standing machine gun tripods and other military equipment from an Army Reserve warehouse in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Adam Rasgon and Ronen Bergman
title: Israeli Security Chiefs Join Critical Talks for a Cease-Fire in Gaza
description: Pressure is on to reach a deal that would see Hamas release at least some hostages before President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office.
content: Israeli security and policy chiefs arrived in Qatar on Sunday for high-level talks about a proposed cease-fire deal in Gaza that would see hostages released in the final days of President Biden’s term and before Donald J. Trump takes office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: In Canada, Long-Suffering N.F.L. Fans Have Reason to Cheer
description: With the Buffalo Bills and Detroit Lions both Super Bowl contenders, fans north of the border are nervously hopeful a title drought could end.
content: About a decade ago, Mike Smith tried to capture the sour mood of the patrons in his neighborhood bar, Joe Kool’s. For years, their favorite sports teams endured winless seasons, playoff droughts and epic collapses, so he designed a T-shirt that included a map of southern Ontario with London in the middle and lines connecting to Buffalo, Cleveland, Detroit and Toronto. Above it were the words “The Epicentre of Losing” and a red arrow pointing at London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Stagehands Walk Off the Job at Atlantic Theater Company
description: The stage employees union accused the nonprofit theater of stalling talks. The strike forced the cancellation of Sunday performances of two new plays.
content: The labor union representing stagehands went on strike Sunday against Atlantic Theater Company in Manhattan, prompting the prestigious nonprofit to postpone two productions that had already begun performances and to warn that union demands could force the closing of the Atlantic and other Off Broadway nonprofits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Misty White Sidell
title: Bonnets Are the Winter Hat of the Moment. For Adults.
description: Grown-up versions of the infant staple have become increasingly sought-after.
content: Each winter, it’s often the case that a specific cold-weather accessory — a rainbow-check scarf, for example — comes to define the season. This year that item appears to be a knit hat that could be described as a baby bonnet for adults. It also evokes a balaclava, leading some sellers to christen it the “balabonnet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon, Nikolay Nikolov and James Surdam
title: Battling Militants Backed by Islamic State in Mozambique
description: For more than seven years, an insurgency backed by the Islamic State has raged across Cabo Delgado, Mozambique, completely upending life in this coastal province rich with natural resources. John Eligon, The New York Times Johannesburg bureau chief, traveled across the province to speak with people trying to rebuild their lives.
content: For more than seven years, an insurgency backed by the Islamic State has raged across Cabo Delgado, Mozambique, completely upending life in this coastal province rich with natural resources. John Eligon, The New York Times Johannesburg bureau chief, traveled across the province to speak with people trying to rebuild their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Pena, Connor Nelson, Josh Finbow, Mark Boyer and Nailah Morgan
title: Community L.A. Fire Brigade Steps In to Help Evacuate Residents
description: Deep into the evacuation zone, volunteers are stepping in to evacuate L.A. residents from encroaching wildfires. Armed with radios, hoses and knowledge of the area, this brigade offers help to overextended fire departments as they try to reach people who have yet to flee.
content: Deep into the evacuation zone, volunteers are stepping in to evacuate L.A. residents from encroaching wildfires. Armed with radios, hoses and knowledge of the area, this brigade offers help to overextended fire departments as they try to reach people who have yet to flee.
source.name: The New York Times
